data.text:
A film genre is a set of conventions and formulas, repeated and developed through film history that organize and categorize film according to repeated subjects, icons, and styles.

Genres describe cultural rituals and follow an economics of predictability.

The Foundations of Film Genre

Early cinema knew about genres because they existed in its predecessors- photography, literature, art, and musical halls.

Conventions, Formulas, and Expectations

A genre is a category or classification of a group of movies in which individual films share similar subject matter and organization of that subject.

Generic conventions are isolated properties or figures that identify a genre through such features as character types, settings, props, or events that are repeated from film to film. These also include iconography.

Generic formulas are principles of arrangement about how to organize generic conventions through a plot. In some cases these can create myths.

Generic expectations describe the experience and knowledge that a viewer activates while watching a film, so that she anticipates the meaning of particular conventions or the direction of certain narrative formulas.

A Short History of Film Genre

Genres have been used to classify works of literature, theatre, painting, music and other arts. For example literature has the broad genres of tragedy and comedy; musical genres include love songs and classical sonatas.

Genres provide models for producing other work, direct audience expectations, and create categories for evaluating a work.

Genre films were mass produced by the studio systems. The Paramount Decision of 1948 effected the production of genre film because the monopoly hold on distribution the studios had was dissolved.

Six Film Genre Paradigms

It may seem daunting to try to create a list of movie genres. Genres are a product of a perspective that groups movies together, which can construct them in many ways. Genre is a multi-dimensional field with two major subsets: hybrid genres and subgenres,

The six central genres are comedy, western, melodrama, musical, horror, and crime films.

Each of these genres have subgenres that include:

For comedy: slapstick, screwball, and romantic

For westerns: western epic, the existential western, and political westerns

For melodramas: physical melodramas, family melodramas, and social melodramas

For musicals: the theatrical musical, the realistic musical, and the animated musical

For horror: the supernatural thriller and psychological horror films

For crime films: gangster films, hard-boiled detective films, and film noir

Values and Traditions in Film Genres

To Prescribe or To Describe

Generic perspective on a movie may promote either prescriptive or descriptive values.

Related to prescriptive values is the tradition of classical genres, and to descriptive values is the tradition of revisionist genres.
